Thus in the expression for $-{\theta}^{-1}$ there are three terms. We handle the proof in two cases:

\noindent \textbf{Case One}: Regular singularity.  

In this case we have $f=\alpha\in \Bbbk-\{0\}$, $s=0$ and $r=1$.  Because $\alpha$ is only defined up to a shift by $\mathbb{Z}$ we can ignore the $\frac{d}{dz_x}$ term.  The remaining portion of the proof is as described in the remark following the outline in subsection \ref{Mellin outline}. Note that since $s=0$, the extra ${\theta}$ term in \eqref{xisyseq2} will vanish.

\noindent \textbf{Case Two}: Irregular singularity.
